metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: React Forms
Just like in HTML, React uses forms to allow users to interact with the web page.
content.html: Just like in HTML, React uses forms to allow users to interact with the web page.

content.text: Adding Forms in React
You add a form with React like any other element:
content.html: You add a form with React like any other element:

content.code:
function

MyForm
(
)

{


return

(


<
form

<

Enter your name:

)


}


const

content.code_html:
function MyForm() {
  return (
    <form>
      <label>Enter your name:
        <input type="text" />
      </label>
    </form>
  )
}
const root = ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root'));
root.render(<MyForm />);

content.text: This will work as normal, the form will submit and the page will refresh.
content.html: This will work as normal, the form will submit and the page will refresh.

content.text: But this is generally not what we want to happen in React.
content.html: But this is generally not what we want to happen in React.

content.text: We want to prevent this default behavior and let React control the form.
content.html: We want to prevent this default behavior and let React control the form.

content.text: Handling Forms
Handling forms is about how you handle the data when it changes value or gets submitted.
content.html: Handling forms is about how you handle the data when it changes value or gets submitted.

content.text: In HTML, form data is usually handled by the DOM.
content.html: In HTML, form data is usually handled by the DOM.

content.text: In React, form data is usually handled by the components.
content.html: In React, form data is usually handled by the components.

content.text: When the data is handled by the components, all the data is stored in the component state.
content.html: When the data is handled by the components, all the data is stored in the component state.

content.text: You can control changes by adding event handlers in the onChange attribute.
content.html: You can control changes by adding event handlers in the onChange attribute.

content.text: We can use the useState Hook to keep track of each inputs value and provide a "single source of truth" for the entire application.
content.html: We can use the useState Hook to keep track of each inputs value and provide a "single source of truth" for the entire application.

content.text: See the React Hooks section for more information on Hooks.
content.html: See the React Hooks section for more information on Hooks.

content.code_html:
import { useState } from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom/client';

function MyForm() {
  const [name, setName] = useState("");

  return (
    <form>
      <label>Enter your name:
        <input
          type="text" 
          value={name}
          onChange={(e) => setName(e.target.value)}
        />
      </label>
    </form>
  )
}

const root = ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root'));
root.render(<MyForm />);

content.text: Submitting Forms
You can control the submit action by adding an event handler in the onSubmit attribute for the <form> :
content.html: You can control the submit action by adding an event handler in the onSubmit attribute for the <form>:

content.code_html:
import { useState } from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom/client';

function MyForm() {
  const [name, setName] = useState("");

  const handleSubmit = (event) => {
    event.preventDefault();
    alert(`The name you entered was: ${name}`)
  }

  return (
    <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
      <label>Enter your name:
        <input 
          type="text" 
          value={name}
          onChange={(e) => setName(e.target.value)}
        />
      </label>
      <input type="submit" />
    </form>
  )
}

const root = ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root'));
root.render(<MyForm />);

content.text: Multiple Input Fields
You can control the values of more than one input field by adding a name attribute to each element.
content.html: You can control the values of more than one input field by adding a name attribute to each element.

content.text: We will initialize our state with an empty object.
content.html: We will initialize our state with an empty object.

content.text: To access the fields in the event handler use the event.target.name and event.target.value syntax.
content.html: To access the fields in the event handler use the event.target.name and event.target.value syntax.

content.text: To update the state, use square brackets [bracket notation] around the property name.
content.html: To update the state, use square brackets [bracket notation] around the property name.

content.code_html:
import { useState } from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom/client';

function MyForm() {
  const [inputs, setInputs] = useState({});

  const handleChange = (event) => {
    const name = event.target.name;
    const value = event.target.value;
    setInputs(values => ({...values, [name]: value}))
  }

  const handleSubmit = (event) => {
    event.preventDefault();
    alert(inputs);
  }

  return (
    <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
      <label>Enter your name:
      <input 
        type="text" 
        name="username" 
        value={inputs.username || ""} 
        onChange={handleChange}
      />
      </label>
      <label>Enter your age:
        <input 
          type="number" 
          name="age" 
          value={inputs.age || ""} 
          onChange={handleChange}
        />
        </label>
        <input type="submit" />
    </form>
  )
}

const root = ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root'));
root.render(<MyForm />);

content.text: Note: We use the same event handler function for both input fields, we could write one event handler for each, but this gives us much cleaner code and is the preferred way in React.
content.html: Note: We use the same event handler function for both input fields, we could write one event handler for each, but this gives us much cleaner code and is the preferred way in React.

content.text: Textarea
The textarea element in React is slightly different from ordinary HTML.
content.html: The textarea element in React is slightly different from ordinary HTML.

content.text: In HTML the value of a textarea was the text between the start tag <textarea> and the end tag </textarea> .
content.html: In HTML the value of a textarea was the text between the start tag <textarea> and the end tag </textarea>.

content.code:
<
textarea
>

Content of the textarea.

</
textarea
>
content.code_html:
<textarea>
  Content of the textarea.
</textarea>

content.text: In React the value of a textarea is placed in a value attribute. We'll use the useState Hook to manage the value of the textarea:
content.html: In React the value of a textarea is placed in a value attribute. We'll use the useState Hook to manage the value of the textarea:

content.code_html:
import { useState } from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom/client';

function MyForm() {
  const [textarea, setTextarea] = useState(
    "The content of a textarea goes in the value attribute"
  );

  const handleChange = (event) => {
    setTextarea(event.target.value)
  }

  return (
    <form>
      <textarea value={textarea} onChange={handleChange} />
    </form>
  )
}

const root = ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root'));
root.render(<MyForm />);

content.text: Select
A drop down list, or a select box, in React is also a bit different from HTML.
content.html: A drop down list, or a select box, in React is also a bit different from HTML.

content.text: In HTML, the selected value in the drop down list was defined with the selected attribute:
content.html: In HTML, the selected value in the drop down list was defined with the selected attribute:

content.code:
<
select
>


<
option

value
=
"
Ford
"
>
Ford
</
option
>


<
option

value
=
"
Volvo
"

selected
>
Volvo
</
option
>


<
option

value
=
"
Fiat
"
>
Fiat
</
option
>


</
select
>
content.code_html:
<select>
  <option value="Ford">Ford</option>
  <option value="Volvo" selected>Volvo</option>
  <option value="Fiat">Fiat</option>
</select>

content.text: In React, the selected value is defined with a value attribute on the select tag:
content.html: In React, the selected value is defined with a value attribute on the select tag:

content.code_html:
function MyForm() {
  const [myCar, setMyCar] = useState("Volvo");

  const handleChange = (event) => {
    setMyCar(event.target.value)
  }

  return (
    <form>
      <select value={myCar} onChange={handleChange}>
        <option value="Ford">Ford</option>
        <option value="Volvo">Volvo</option>
        <option value="Fiat">Fiat</option>
      </select>
    </form>
  )
}

content.text: By making these slight changes to <textarea> and <select> , React is able to handle all input elements in the same way.
content.html: By making these slight changes to <textarea> and <select>, React is able to handle all input elements in the same way.
